title: View of the Amsterdam Harbour from the Sea
content:
accession_no_csv: 2018-00057

  Image: 

  object_work_type: copper engravings (visual works) engravings (prints)

  title_text: View of the Amsterdam Harbour from the Sea

  preference: main

  title_language: 

  creator_2: Hendrik de Leth Johannes Covens and Cornelis Mortier

  creator_1: not indicated

  creator_role: engravers (printmakers) publishers

  creation_date: c1740

  creation_place_original_location: Amsterdam (inhabited place)\r\n

  styles_periods_indexing_terms: not indicated

  inscriptions: 

  inscription_language: 

  shape: rectangular

  materials_name: paper (fiber product)

  techniques_name: papermaking copper engraving (printing process) hand coloring

  object_colour: multicoloured

  physical_appearance: This print shows the view of the Amsterdam Harbour from the sea. There are two lines of text centralised at the top of the print. The legend
 comprising five lines of text in Dutch and numbered one to twenty-seven on both halves of the print
 can also be seen at the bottom of the print. The legend provides details of the important buildings portrayed in the print.

  subject_terms_1: harbours merchant vessels

  subject_terms_2: Harbours Engravings

  subject_terms_3: Harbours

  sgcool_label_text: This is a view of the Amsterdam harbour from the inlet known as the IJ. The harbour is depicted as bustling with activities with a variety of shipping vessels dominated by a large mewrchant vessel in the foreground. The profile of the city is visible in the background
 with a detailed legend below identifying major buildings. The print was produced by Hendrik de Leth
 and published by Johannes Covens and Cornelis Mortier.

metadata.title_text: View of the Amsterdam Harbour from the Sea
metadata.creator_2: Hendrik de Leth Johannes Covens and Cornelis Mortier
metadata.techniques_name: papermaking copper engraving (printing process) hand coloring
metadata.physical_appearance: This print shows the view of the Amsterdam Harbour from the sea. There are two lines of text centralised at the top of the print. The legend, comprising five lines of text in Dutch and numbered one to twenty-seven on both halves of the print, can also be seen at the bottom of the print. The legend provides details of the important buildings portrayed in the print.
metadata.sgcool_label_text: This is a view of the Amsterdam harbour from the inlet known as the IJ. The harbour is depicted as bustling with activities with a variety of shipping vessels dominated by a large mewrchant vessel in the foreground. The profile of the city is visible in the background, with a detailed legend below identifying major buildings. The print was produced by Hendrik de Leth, and published by Johannes Covens and Cornelis Mortier.
